title: The things engineers are desperate for PMs to understand | Camille Fournier (“The Manager’s Path”)
themes: technical decision making and system rewrites
key_insights: PMs should avoid hoarding credit, playing telephone between stakeholders, and dismissing technical details to maintain good relationships with engineers
Engineers need creative outlets in product decisions, or they'll find them in unnecessary technical rewrites and over-engineering
Major system rewrites are often traps that underestimate migration complexity and hidden business logic in legacy systems
Engineering managers should achieve technical mastery (around 10 years) before transitioning to management to maintain credibility
Platform teams need software engineers, product managers, and outcome-based metrics - not just DevOps/SRE roles
Working fewer focused hours with regular audits of priorities often produces better results than long work weeks
Effective delegation requires upfront teaching investment but creates scalability and team empowerment
One-on-ones should be reserved for direct reports and managers, not used as default stakeholder management
topics_discussed: Common PM behaviors that annoy engineers
Credit sharing and inclusive leadership practices
The dangers of major system rewrites
Finding balance between technical depth and leadership altitude
Transition timing from IC to engineering management
Building effective work cultures without overwork
AI tools for writing and productivity
memorable_quotes: If you don't challenge yourself, if you don't take risks, you'll never grow
Management really is a service job. You are serving the team, you are serving the company
Overwork kind of lets you just sidestep doing the hard work of figuring out what's important in the first place
recommended_for: Product managers working with engineering teams
summary: Camille Fournier shares hard-won wisdom on PM-engineering relationships, the realities of engineering leadership, and building effective platform teams. The conversation offers specific tactics for avoiding common pitfalls while emphasizing the importance of focus, delegation, and servant leadership in technical organizations.
